title: Forgot to declare equipment in CH7 - what can they do?
question: I filed CH 7 3 weeks ago and I have two laptops I ordered on a Best Buy credit card - one was 2 months ago and a second a few weeks before I filed CH7. I spaced and forgot to list them in my BK filing (my lawyer is out of town and I am trying to find an answer today). The filing was made last week.
answers:
First off, try not to stress out about filing the amendment TODAY. An amendment can be filed at any time before the case is discharged, even after the 341 meeting. Just be sure to mention these circumstances to your attorney before you go into the meeting and typically Trustee asks if there are any changes to make to the petition and that is your opportunity to disclose and explain that you forgot to list this item. It is not unusual, although all efforts are made to prevent this, for a debtor to forget something on their petition.

Your attorney will want to amend Statement of Financial Affairs and discuss the theft of the items. In my experience, Best Buy doesn't come to the 341 but they do send letter and/or call your attorney to discuss reaffirming the debt, settling amounts owed, or turning over the property in question. Reason for this is that unlike other credit cards, store credit cards, as other counsel pointed out, typically have a security interest in the purchased items. Also, the purchase so close to the filing is another issue. Discuss this with your attorney, there is time to get this straightened out. The best route is to disclose even if the facts are bad and deal with them, not hide them. If you are honest and disclose, the worst thing that can happen is that you might have to pay for the laptops. If you are dishonest and don't disclose the information, you risk your entire case as a bad faith petitioner.

You will find that Best Buy may very well have a representative who will show up at your 341a hearing. When you charge an item at Best Buy they retain a security interest in the goods and can demand that you either return the item or pay for it. Sometimes they will accept less than what is owed under the contract, but they are under no obligation to. Because you charged the laptops so close to the date you filed your petition there is a presumption that you were planning to file your bankruptcy when you made the purchases. The debt underlying a charge made on the eve of filing a bankruptcy petition can be non-dischargeable so you will have to pay it, whether or not you still have the goods.

You absolutely have to amend your schedules. You signed them under penalty of perjury and the trustee will ask you at your meeting if everything in your petition is true and correct. If you fail to amend your petition and disclose the items you can be prosecuted for fraud.

You might want to check with your insurance company to see if there is any coverage for items which might have been stolen during an open house. You also need to file a police report.

You need to amend your schedule to list them.

However, it is important you tell your attorney when you incurred the debt. You have a potential objection to your discharge for fraud.

Any large purchases within 90 of filing has a presumption of fraud.

The problem I see with this equipment you forgot to list is that they were purchased so close to filing of your chapter 7. In NC. where I practice you would not be able to claim them as exempt because they were purchased within 90 days of the filing date. Additionally, they were bought very close to the filing date so there would be a legitimate question of whether you intended to repay the debt (assuming you financed them) when you incurred the debt. If they were stolen during an open house, have you filed a police report? A claim with your insurance?

Call your lawyer ASAP and advise him about this.

You need to amend your bankruptcy petition and include them. This shouldn't be too difficult because you probably have not had your 341(a) hearing yet since you filed 3 weeks ago. Some electronics, appliance, and furniture stores actually take out a security interest in their goods which means your credit card debt to best buy might be a secured debt. Your attorney can help you figure this out by looking at the sales agreement.

If it is not secured and is an unsecured debt like your other credit card debts, then you will simply amend your petition and nothing will change. If the purchase was secured, then best buy has a right to seize the laptops. However, seeing as how they were stolen, you may have to reimburse best buy for the value because they were your responsibility, unless you had theft insurance on the laptops.

I would also like to say that many attorneys (including myself) warn prospective bankruptcy clients not to make any credit card purchases in the 3 months before filing for bankruptcy. Especially purchases for "luxury goods" which includes designer clothing, electronics, appliances, vacation trips, etc. The reason is that a bankruptcy trustee may deem such purchases as fraudulent.

Please speak with your attorney as soon as possible and tell him or her to amend your petition and also figure out whether your laptop purchases were secured or not.

You may think "what is the harm?" but the first time someone (either the Court, the U.S. Trustee, the chapter 7 trustee or your OWN attorney) loses any faith in your candor, the ability to have your case go smoothly is possibly forever lost.

Basic rule of thumb -- tell the truth and disclose the fact that you forgot to list the computers and they are now missing. Otherwise, if you do not disclose and it becomes discovered no thanks to you, well, you will look as guilty as every defendant on CSI or Without A Trace or similar show that claims they did not disclose material information because . . . [fill in a feeble excuse -- and they all are feeble excuses]. You will also be guilty of failing to correct a mistake and then hiding the fact that you made a mistake.

Finally, be respectful to your attorney and the process -- tell him or her and go from there.
You can file an amendment to your schedules to lost all of the assets. Its not a big deal to do and your attorney can file it. You should be fine as long as its before your 341a meeting.
